docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama, already under scrutiny from some liberal groups for having agreed with Republicans to extend the Bush-era tax cuts across all income brackets, would seem have invited additional criticism from the left with his unforgiving rhetoric toward them in his press conference this afternoon.

headline.main: Obama's Tough Words for Liberals: Truth or Dare?

docs.abstract: The left may be unhappy with the tax cut compromise, but where does it turn?
docs.snippet: The left may be unhappy with the tax cut compromise, but where does it turn?

docs.lead_paragraph: Grow a spine. Flex some muscle. Man up! In Twitter-speak, the advice to President Obama from his disheartened liberal base is to bulk up on the political equivalent of steroids, something to make this most cerebral of presidents more ripped and less reserved. They want ''Bring It On, the Sequel'': let Republicans deny unemployment benefits for two million people at Christmastime while giving Mr. Potter and his ilk another tax break.
docs.abstract: Timothy Egan Op-Ed column explores mystifying paradox of Obama presidency--that such a gifted orator has not been able to come up with simple, over-arching governing frame; contends that to change master narrative of his presidency, Obama must find that one Big Idea, understood by all, that would show him to be on side of average Americans, making them truly believe that country is moving in right direction under his leadership (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jackie Hoffman caustically comments on her life so far (up to 50) and her theater career in “Jackie Five-Oh!,” at Joe’s Pub.

headline.seo: Jackie Hoffman’s  ‘Jackie Five-Oh!’ at Joe’s Pub - Review

docs.snippet: Jackie Hoffman caustically comments on her life so far (up to 50) and her theater career in “Jackie Five-Oh!,” at Joe’s Pub.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I would have won a Tony if there had been a category called Hating Other People's Careers While Combining Maker's Mark, Ambien and Pinkberry,'' Jackie Hoffman announced during ''Jackie Five-Oh!,'' her latest caustic cabaret show. She may be gainfully employed six days a week playing Grandma in ''The Addams Family,'' but as Ms. Hoffman's fans know, that doesn't stop her biting the Broadway hand that feeds her. And resentment mixes well with the cocktails in her savagely funny sixth original show at Joe's Pub.

docs.lead_paragraph: FREEMAN--Houghton "Buck," dearly loved husband of Doreen for over 62 years, passed away in Stowe, VT, on Wednesday, December 1, 2010. He is deeply mourned by his beloved son, Graeme Freeman, and his wife, Nancy, of Honolulu, HI, and daughter, Linda Post, and her husband, Don, of Stowe, VT. Equally loved were his grandchildren, Alec and Colin Freeman; Tyler, Alexi, and Graham Post; and stepgrandsons, David and Scott DeCristo. Buck Freeman was born in Peking, China, in 1921, the son of Professor Mansfield Freeman and his wife, Mary Houghton. He graduated from the Shanghai American School and then attended Wesleyan University in Middletown, CT. After this, he entered the US Navy and attended the Japanese Language Schools in Berkeley, CA, and Boulder, CO. He returned to Wesleyan and graduated in 1946. He began his insurance career with American International Underwriters Corporation. After training at Lloyds of London and marrying Doreen Brown in London in 1948, he was transferred to Shanghai, China, where his daughter, Linda, was born in 1949. Upon evacuation from Shanghai, they relocated to Tokyo, Japan. He was appointed Resident Vice President of AIU Japan in 1952; his son, Graeme, was born in St. Johnsbury, VT, in 1955; and he was appointed President of AIU Japan in 1956. He remained in Japan for 21 years before moving to New York. In 1983, he was elected President and Chief Operating Officer of American International Group (AIG). Upon his retirement in 1993, he remained an honorary Director of AIG. Upon his father's death in 1992, Mr. Freeman assumed position of Chairman of the Freeman Foundation which he ran with his wife and son until his death. A Memorial Service will take place in early summer in Greensboro, VT. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Lamoille Home Health and Hospice, 54 Farr Ave, Morrisville, VT, 05661; American Red Cross, Hawaii State Chapter, 4155 Diamond Head Rd, Honolulu, HI 96816; or a charity of your choice.
